<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TaskGetInfo(osal_id_t task_id, OS_task_prop_t *task_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *       record;
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(task_prop);

    memset(task_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_task_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_task_table, token);
        task   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            strncpy(task_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(task_prop->name) - 1);
            task_prop->name[sizeof(task_prop->name) - 1] = 0;
        }
        task_prop->creator    = record->creator;
        task_prop->stack_size = task->stack_size;
        task_prop->priority   = task->priority;

        return_code = OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl(&token, task_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: Only code fragments that invoke or directly manipulate string/byte operations are reported for investigation. Other lines in the function do not call any of the <string.h> functions listed by the rule (e.g. variable declarations, OS_ObjectIdGetById/OS_ObjectIdRelease calls, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro use, assignments of numeric fields, and the call to OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl). Those do not themselves perform string/byte copying or memory setting and therefore are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 and do not need further investigation here.
